newsitem.title: IRAN: Iran says higher oil price indicates OPEC restraint.
newsitem.headline: Iran says higher oil price indicates OPEC restraint.

text.p: A $2.50 a barrel rise in world oil prices indicated lower output from the Organisation of the Petroleum Exporting Countries (OPEC), Iran Oil Minister Gholamreza Aghazadeh was reported as saying on Tuesday.
In a report by the official Iranian news agency IRNA, Aghazadeh was also reported to have said that all 11 OPEC members were producing at their individual quotas levels.

"Following agreements reached at the supervising committee of OPEC held recently in Isfahan no quota violations have been reported in the production of the member countries and the 11 members are observing their quotas," IRNA reported from Tehran.
The nearby Brent crude futures contract on London's International Petroleum Exchange rose from a low of $17.87 on May 6 to a high of $20.60 on May 16.
Aghazadeh chaired a meeting of seven OPEC ministers in the Iranian city of Isfahan in early May on the sidelines of an international energy conference.

That meeting called on all OPEC states to respect their quotas in an attempt to rein in the group's output, which independent assessments put at more than 27 million barrels per day (bpd) compared to an agreed ceiling of 25.03 million bpd.
Aghazadeh was speaking in Tehran after returning from a trip to China and South Korea which included a meeting with Chinese Prime Minister Li Peng.
